title: Commemoration as Conflict: continuing the 'war by other means'.
abstractText:
This project investigates the ways in which the processes and practices of commemoration are used as a surrogate means of perpetuating conflict during the negotiation of formal peace agreements or of reactivating conflict as political circumstances change.

There are four precise research questions:

  • How are commemoration and memorialisation used during the successive stages of a peace process and the transition from armed conflict?
  • Can the contesting parties in a peace process reconcile partisan commemoration and material landscapes of memorialisation, aimed at enhancing ethnic or group solidarity and integrity, with the ostensibly more pluralist context of a peace process?
  • In what ways can these processes and practices of commemoration and memorialisation be used as a surrogate means of conflict, especially in staking out territorial claims and maintaining identity homogeneity?
  • What particular roles do commemoration and memorialisation play both in impeding but also facilitating the negotiation of peace processes across a range of conflicts?

The project involves the application of a range of integrated qualitative methodologies to five very different case studies: Sri Lanka, the Basque Country, Israel/Palestine, the former Yugoslavia and South Africa. These include: desk-based research; semi-structured interviews; fieldwork observation; visual approaches and document analysis.
